_Peripheral nervous system_

Identifiers  
Acronym(s) | PNS  
[TA](/wiki/Terminologia_Anatomica "Terminologia Anatomica") | [A14.2.00.001](http://www.unifr.ch/ifaa/Public/EntryPage/TA98%20Tree/Entity%20TA98%20EN/14.2.00.001%20Entity%20TA98%20EN.htm)  
[FMA](/wiki/Foundational_Model_of_Anatomy "Foundational Model of Anatomy") | [9903](http://xiphoid.biostr.washington.edu/fma/fmabrowser-hierarchy.html?fmaid=9903)  
**_[Anatomical terms of neuroanatomy](/wiki/Anatomical_terms_of_neuroanatomy
"Anatomical terms of neuroanatomy")_** [[edit on
Wikidata](https://www.wikidata.org/wiki/Q169953 "d:Q169953")]  
  
The **peripheral nervous system** (**PNS**) is one of the two components of
the [nervous system](/wiki/Nervous_system "Nervous system"), the other part is
the [central nervous system](/wiki/Central_nervous_system "Central nervous
system") (CNS). The PNS consists of the [nerves](/wiki/Nerve "Nerve") and
[ganglia](/wiki/Ganglia "Ganglia") outside the [brain](/wiki/Brain "Brain")
and [spinal cord](/wiki/Spinal_cord "Spinal cord").[1] The main function of
the PNS is to connect the CNS to the limbs and organs, essentially serving as
a relay between the brain and spinal cord and the rest of the body.[2] Unlike
the CNS, the PNS is not protected by the [vertebral
column](/wiki/Vertebral_column "Vertebral column") and [skull](/wiki/Skull
"Skull"), or by the [blood–brain barrier](/wiki/Blood%E2%80%93brain_barrier
"Blood–brain barrier"), which leaves it exposed to [toxins](/wiki/Toxin
"Toxin") and mechanical injuries. The peripheral nervous system is divided
into the [somatic nervous system](/wiki/Somatic_nervous_system "Somatic
nervous system") and the [autonomic nervous
system](/wiki/Autonomic_nervous_system "Autonomic nervous system"). In the
somatic nervous system, the [cranial nerves](/wiki/Cranial_nerve "Cranial
nerve") are part of the PNS with the exception of the [optic
nerve](/wiki/Optic_nerve "Optic nerve") (cranial nerve II), along with the
[retina](/wiki/Retina "Retina"). The second cranial nerve is not a true
peripheral nerve but a tract of the [diencephalon](/wiki/Diencephalon
"Diencephalon").[3] Cranial nerve ganglia originated in the CNS. However, the
remaining ten cranial nerve [axons](/wiki/Axon "Axon") extend beyond the brain
and are therefore considered part of the PNS.[4] The autonomic nervous system
is an involuntary control of smooth muscle and glands. The connection between
CNS and organs allows the system to be in two different functional states:
[sympathetic](/wiki/Sympathetic_nervous_system "Sympathetic nervous system")
and [parasympathetic](/wiki/Parasympathetic_nervous_system "Parasympathetic
nervous system").

##
Structure[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Peripheral_nervous_system&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Structure")]

The peripheral nervous system is divided into the [somatic nervous
system](/wiki/Somatic_nervous_system "Somatic nervous system"), and the
[autonomic nervous system](/wiki/Autonomic_nervous_system "Autonomic nervous
system"). The somatic nervous system is under voluntary control, and transmits
signals from the brain to end organs such as [muscle](/wiki/Muscle "Muscle")s.
The [sensory nervous system](/wiki/Sensory_nervous_system "Sensory nervous
system") is part of the somatic nervous system and transmits signals from
senses such as [taste](/wiki/Taste "Taste") and touch (including fine touch
and gross touch) to the spinal cord and brain. The autonomic nervous system is
a 'self-regulating' system which influences the function of organs outside
voluntary control, such as the [heart rate](/wiki/Heart_rate "Heart rate"), or
the functions of the [digestive system](/wiki/Human_digestive_system "Human
digestive system").

### Somatic nervous
system[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Peripheral_nervous_system&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Somatic nervous system")]

See also: [List of nerves of the human
body](/wiki/List_of_nerves_of_the_human_body "List of nerves of the human
body")

The somatic system includes the [sensory nervous
system](/wiki/Sensory_nervous_system "Sensory nervous system") and the
[somatosensory system](/wiki/Somatosensory_system "Somatosensory system") and
consists of sensory nerves and somatic nerves, and many nerves which hold both
functions.

In the [head](/wiki/Head "Head") and [neck](/wiki/Neck "Neck"), [cranial
nerve](/wiki/Cranial_nerve "Cranial nerve")s carry somatosensory data. There
are twelve cranial nerves, ten of which originate from the
[brainstem](/wiki/Brainstem "Brainstem"), and mainly control the functions of
the anatomic structures of the head with some exceptions. The nuclei of the
[olfactory nerve](/wiki/Olfactory_nerve "Olfactory nerve") and the [optic
nerve](/wiki/Optic_nerve "Optic nerve")s lie in the forebrain and thalamus,
respectively, and are thus not considered to be true cranial nerves. One
unique cranial nerve is the [vagus nerve](/wiki/Vagus_nerve "Vagus nerve"),
which receives sensory information from organs in the thorax and abdomen. The
[accessory nerve](/wiki/Accessory_nerve "Accessory nerve") is responsible for
innervating the [sternocleidomastoid](/wiki/Sternocleidomastoid_muscle
"Sternocleidomastoid muscle") and [trapezius muscles](/wiki/Trapezius_muscle
"Trapezius muscle"), neither of which being exclusively in the head.

For the rest of the body, [spinal nerves](/wiki/Spinal_nerve "Spinal nerve")
are responsible for somatosensory information. These arise from the [spinal
cord](/wiki/Spinal_cord "Spinal cord"). Usually these arise as a web
("plexus") of interconnected nerves roots that arrange to form single nerves.
These nerves control the functions of the rest of the body. In humans, there
are 31 pairs of spinal nerves: 8 cervical, 12 thoracic, 5 lumbar, 5 sacral and
1 coccygeal. These nerve roots are named according to the spinal vertebrata
which they are adjacent to. In the cervical region, the spinal nerve roots
come out _above_ the corresponding vertebrae (i.e., nerve root between the
skull and 1st cervical vertebrae is called spinal nerve C1). From the thoracic
region to the coccygeal region, the spinal nerve roots come out _below_ the
corresponding vertebrae. It is important to note that this method creates a
problem when naming the spinal nerve root between C7 and T1 (so it is called
spinal nerve root C8). In the lumbar and sacral region, the spinal nerve roots
travel within the dural sac and they travel below the level of L2 as the cauda
equina.

#### Cervical spinal nerves
(C1–C4)[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Peripheral_nervous_system&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Cervical spinal nerves \(C1–C4\)")]

Further information: [Cervical plexus](/wiki/Cervical_plexus "Cervical
plexus")

The first 4 cervical spinal nerves, C1 through C4, split and recombine to
produce a variety of nerves that serve the neck and back of head.

Spinal nerve C1 is called the [suboccipital nerve](/wiki/Suboccipital_nerve
"Suboccipital nerve"), which provides motor innervation to muscles at the base
of the [skull](/wiki/Skull "Skull"). C2 and C3 form many of the nerves of the
neck, providing both sensory and motor control. These include the [greater
occipital nerve](/wiki/Greater_occipital_nerve "Greater occipital nerve"),
which provides sensation to the back of the head, the [lesser occipital
nerve](/wiki/Lesser_occipital_nerve "Lesser occipital nerve"), which provides
sensation to the area behind the [ears](/wiki/Ear "Ear"), the [greater
auricular nerve](/wiki/Greater_auricular_nerve "Greater auricular nerve") and
the [lesser auricular nerve](/wiki/Lesser_auricular_nerve "Lesser auricular
nerve").

The [phrenic nerve](/wiki/Phrenic_nerve "Phrenic nerve") is a nerve essential
for our survival which arises from nerve roots C3, C4 and C5. It supplies the
[thoracic diaphragm](/wiki/Thoracic_diaphragm "Thoracic diaphragm"), enabling
[breathing](/wiki/Breathing "Breathing"). If the spinal cord is transected
above C3, then spontaneous breathing is not possible.

#### Brachial plexus
(C5–T1)[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Peripheral_nervous_system&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Brachial plexus \(C5–T1\)")]

Further information: [Brachial plexus](/wiki/Brachial_plexus "Brachial
plexus")

The last four cervical spinal nerves, C5 through C8, and the first thoracic
spinal nerve, T1, combine to form the [brachial plexus](/wiki/Brachial_plexus
"Brachial plexus"), or plexus brachialis, a tangled array of nerves,
splitting, combining and recombining, to form the nerves that subserve the
upper-limb and upper back. Although the brachial plexus may appear tangled, it
is highly organized and predictable, with little variation between people. See
[brachial plexus injuries](/wiki/Brachial_plexus_injuries "Brachial plexus
injuries").

#### Lumbosacral plexus
(L1–Co1)[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Peripheral_nervous_system&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: Lumbosacral plexus \(L1–Co1\)")]

The [anterior](/wiki/Anterior "Anterior") divisions of the [lumbar
nerves](/wiki/Lumbar_nerves "Lumbar nerves"), [sacral
nerves](/wiki/Sacral_nerves "Sacral nerves"), and [coccygeal
nerve](/wiki/Coccygeal_nerve "Coccygeal nerve") form the [lumbosacral
plexus](/wiki/Lumbosacral_plexus "Lumbosacral plexus"), the first lumbar nerve
being frequently joined by a branch from the [twelfth
thoracic](/wiki/Twelfth_thoracic "Twelfth thoracic"). For descriptive purposes
this plexus is usually divided into three parts:

  * [lumbar plexus](/wiki/Lumbar_plexus "Lumbar plexus")
  * [sacral plexus](/wiki/Sacral_plexus "Sacral plexus")
  * [pudendal plexus](/wiki/Pudendal_plexus_\(nerves\) "Pudendal plexus \(nerves\)")

### Autonomic nervous
system[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Peripheral_nervous_system&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: Autonomic nervous system")]

The [autonomic nervous system](/wiki/Autonomic_nervous_system "Autonomic
nervous system") controls involuntary responses to regulate physiological
functions.[5] The brain and spinal cord from the [central nervous
system](/wiki/Central_nervous_system "Central nervous system") are connected
with organs that have smooth muscle, such as the heart, bladder, and other
cardiac, exocrine, and endocrine related organs, by ganglionic neurons.[5] The
most notable physiological effects from autonomic activity are pupil
constriction and dilation, and salivation of saliva.[5] The autonomic nervous
system is always activated, but is either in the sympathetic or
parasympathetic state.[5] Depending on the situation, one state can overshadow
the other, resulting in a release of different kinds of
[neurotransmitters](/wiki/Neurotransmitters "Neurotransmitters").[5] There is
a lesser known division of the autonomic nervous system known as the [enteric
nervous system](/wiki/Enteric_nervous_system "Enteric nervous system").[6]
Located only around the digestive tract, this system allows for local control
without input from the sympathetic or the parasympathetic branches, though it
can still receive and respond to signals from the rest of the body.[6] The
enteric system is responsible for various functions related to
gastrointestinal system.[6]

#### Sympathetic nervous
system[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Peripheral_nervous_system&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: Sympathetic nervous system")]

The [sympathetic system](/wiki/Sympathetic_system "Sympathetic system") is
activated during a “fight or flight” situation in which great mental stress or
physical danger is encountered.[5] Neurotransmitters such as
[norepinephrine](/wiki/Norepinephrine "Norepinephrine"), and
[epinephrine](/wiki/Epinephrine "Epinephrine") are released,[5] which
increases heart rate and blood flow in certain areas like muscle, while
simultaneously decreasing activities of non-critical functions for survival,
like digestion.[6] The systems are independent to each other, which allows
activation of certain parts of the body, while others remain rested.[6]

#### Parasympathetic nervous
system[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Peripheral_nervous_system&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: Parasympathetic nervous system")]

Primarily using the neurotransmitter [acetylcholine](/wiki/Acetylcholine
"Acetylcholine") (ACh) as a mediator, the [parasympathetic
system](/wiki/Parasympathetic_system "Parasympathetic system") allows the body
to function in a “rest and digest” state.[6] Consequently, when the
parasympathetic system dominates the body, there are increases in salivation
and activities in digestion, while heart rate and other sympathetic response
decrease.[6] Unlike the sympathetic system, humans have some voluntary
controls in the parasympathetic system. The most prominent examples of this
control are urination and defecation.[6]

##
Disease[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Peripheral_nervous_system&action=edit&section=9
"Edit section: Disease")]

Main article: [Peripheral neuropathy](/wiki/Peripheral_neuropathy "Peripheral
neuropathy")

Diseases of the peripheral nervous system can be specific to one or more
nerves, or affect the system as a whole.

Any peripheral nerve or nerve root can be damaged, called a
[mononeuropathy](/wiki/Mononeuropathy "Mononeuropathy"). Such injuries can be
because of injury or trauma, or [compression](/wiki/Compression_neuropathy
"Compression neuropathy"). Compression of nerves can occur because of a tumour
mass or injury. Alternatively, if a nerve is in an area with a fixed size it
may be trapped if the other components increase in size, such as [carpal
tunnel syndrome](/wiki/Carpal_tunnel_syndrome "Carpal tunnel syndrome") and
[tarsal tunnel syndrome](/wiki/Tarsal_tunnel_syndrome "Tarsal tunnel
syndrome"). Common symptoms of [carpal tunnel
syndrome](/wiki/Carpal_tunnel_syndrome "Carpal tunnel syndrome") include pain
and numbness in the thumb, index and middle finger. In peripheral neuropathy,
the function one or more nerves are damaged through a variety of means. Toxic
damage may occur because of diabetes ([diabetic
neuropathy](/wiki/Diabetic_neuropathy "Diabetic neuropathy")), alcohol, heavy
metals or other toxins; some infections; autoimmune and inflammatory
conditions such as [amyloidosis](/wiki/Amyloidosis "Amyloidosis") and
[sarcoidosis](/wiki/Sarcoidosis "Sarcoidosis").[5] Peripheral neuropathy is
associated with a sensory loss in a "glove and stocking" distribution that
begins at the peripheral and slowly progresses upwards, and may also be
associated with acute and chronic pain. Peripheral neuropathy is not just
limited to the somatosensory nerves, but the autonomic nervous system too
([autonomic neuropathy](/wiki/Autonomic_neuropathy "Autonomic
neuropathy")).[5]
